case_name: State of Bihar v. the respondent

facts.text: This is an appeal by the State of Bihar against the judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Patna.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by the State of Bihar against the judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Patna whereby the High Court passed a decree for arrears of salary of the respondent against the State from the 30th July, 1940, up to the date of the institution of the suit.

facts.text: High Court passed a decree for arrears of salary of the respondent against the State from the 30th July, 1940, up to the date of the institution of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: whereby the High Court passed a decree for arrears of salary of the respondent against the State from the 30th July, 1940, up to the date of the institution of the suit. The undisputed facts of the case areThat the respondent was appointed a Sub-Inspector of Police by the Inspector-General of Police, Bihar and Orissa, in January, 1920.

facts.text: The respondent was appointed a Sub-Inspector of Police by the Inspector-General of Police, Bihar and Orissa, in January, 1920.

anchor.surface_text: The undisputed facts of the case areThat the respondent was appointed a Sub-Inspector of Police by the Inspector-General of Police, Bihar and Orissa, in January, 1920. In the year 1937 departmental proceedings were taken against him and he was found guilty of companyardice and of number preparing search lists and was punished by demotion for ten years.

facts.text: In the year 1937 departmental proceedings were taken against the respondent and he was found guilty of cowardice and of not preparing search lists and was punished by demotion for ten years.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1937 departmental proceedings were taken against him and he was found guilty of companyardice and of number preparing search lists and was punished by demotion for ten years. On appeal the Deputy Inspector-General of Police held that the respondent was guilty of companyardice but acquitted him of the other charge.

facts.text: On appeal the Deputy Inspector-General of Police held that the respondent was guilty of cowardice but acquitted him of the other charge.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Deputy Inspector-General of Police held that the respondent was guilty of companyardice but acquitted him of the other charge. By an order dated the 23rd July, 1940, which was companynunicated to the respondent on the 29th of July, 1940, the Deputy Inspector-General of Police having found him guilty of companyardice made an order dismissing him from service.

facts.text: By an order dated the 23rd July, 1940, communicated to the respondent on the 29th of July, 1940, the Deputy Inspector-General of Police dismissed the respondent from service.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated the 23rd July, 1940, which was companynunicated to the respondent on the 29th of July, 1940, the Deputy Inspector-General of Police having found him guilty of companyardice made an order dismissing him from service. Further appeals by the respondent to the Inspector- General of Police and to the Governor of Bihar were unsuccessful.

facts.text: Further appeals by the respondent to the Inspector-General of Police and to the Governor of Bihar were unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: Further appeals by the respondent to the Inspector- General of Police and to the Governor of Bihar were unsuccessful. Aggrieved by the departmental action taken against him, the respondent filed the suit out of which this appeal arises in the companyrt of additional subordinate judge against the State of Bihar for a declaration that the order of the Deputy Inspector-General of Police dismissing him from service was illegal and void and that he should be regarded as companytinuing in office.

facts.text: The respondent filed the suit in the court of additional subordinate judge against the State of Bihar for declaration that dismissal order illegal and void, continuing in office, and Rs. 4,241 arrears from 30th July 1940 to suit date.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the departmental action taken against him, the respondent filed the suit out of which this appeal arises in the companyrt of additional subordinate judge against the State of Bihar for a declaration that the order of the Deputy Inspector-General of Police dismissing him from service was illegal and void and that he should be regarded as companytinuing in office. He also claimed a sum of Rs. 4,241 from 30th July, 1940, to the date of the suit on account of arrears of salary.

facts.text: The State contested the claim and pleaded that the plaintiff held service at pleasure of Crown, could not question dismissal, and reinstated from 30th July 1940 so suit infructuous.

anchor.surface_text: The State companytested the claim and pleaded that the plaintiff held his service at the pleasure of the Crown, and companyld number call in question the grounds or the reasons which led to his dismissal, and that in any case he had been reinstated in service from the 30th of July, 1940, and the order of dismissal therefore was numberlonger operative, and the suit had thus become infructuous.

facts.text: Additional subordinate judge by judgment dated 2nd February 1945 dismissed the suit finding no cause of action due to reinstatement, arrears per rule 95.

anchor.surface_text: The additional subordinate judge by his judgment dated the 2nd February, 1945, dismissed the suit on the finding that the Government having reinstated the respondent he had numbercause of action. As regards the arrears of salary, it was held that the claim to it companyld only be made according to the procedure prescribed under rule 95 of section 4-of Chapter IV of Bihar and Orissa Service Code.

facts.text: Decision confirmed in appeal by additional district judge.

anchor.surface_text: This decision was companyfirmed in appeal by the additional district judge. On further appeal the High Court reversed these decisions and decreed the claim for arrears of salary in the sum of Rs. 3,099-12-0.

facts.text: High Court reversed lower decisions and decreed arrears Rs. 3,099-12-0 dated 5th May 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal the High Court reversed these decisions and decreed the claim for arrears of salary in the sum of Rs. 3,099-12-0. It was held that rule 95 of the Bihar and Orissa Service Code had numberapplication because the respondent had never been dismissed within the meaning of that rule.

facts.text: Government reinstated the respondent by telegram of 30th December 1943 after suit filed.

anchor.surface_text: After the institution of the suit, the Chief Secretary to the Government of Bihar realising the untenability of the Governments position wrote to the Inspector-General of Police that the order of dismissal should be treated as null and void and that the respondent should be reinstated. Thus the reinstatement of the plaintiff the telegram of the 30th December, 1943,

facts.text: Dismissal by Deputy Inspector-General contrary to section 240(3) of Government of India Act 1935 as subordinate to appointing authority.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent here was dismissed by the Deputy Inspector-General of Police, though he was appointed by the Inspector-General of Police. This was clearly companytrary to the  1  1947 F.C.R. 89.  2  75 I.A. 225.  3  75 I.A. 343. provisions of section 240  3  of the Government of India Act, 1935, which provides that numberperson shall be dismissed from the service of His Majesty by an authority subordinate to that by which he was appointed.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from High Court judgment dated 5th May 1949 in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 2091 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 70 of 1952. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Decree dated the 5th May, 1949, of the High Court of Judicature at Patna  Manohar Lall and Mahabir Prasad JJ.  in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 2091 of 1946.

facts.text: Chief Secretary wrote to Inspector-General that dismissal order null and void and respondent reinstated.

anchor.surface_text: After the institution of the suit, the Chief Secretary to the Government of Bihar realising the untenability of the Governments position wrote to the Inspector-General of Police that the order of dismissal should be treated as null and void and that the respondent should be reinstated.

facts.text: Rule 95 of Bihar and Orissa Service Code has no application as no reinstatement by revising or appellate authority.

anchor.surface_text: Obviously these provisions have numberapplication to the situation that arose in the present case. The respondent here was dismissed by the Deputy Inspector-General of Police, though he was appointed by the Inspector-General of Police.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 11, 1954 by MAHAJAN G.J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. February 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MAHAJAN G.I.--This is an appeal by the State of Bihar against the judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Patna whereby the High Court passed a decree for arrears of salary of the respondent against the State from the 30th July, 1940, up to the date of the institution of the suit.

facts.text: High Court held rule 95 no application as respondent never dismissed within meaning of rule.

anchor.surface_text: It was held that rule 95 of the Bihar and Orissa Service Code had numberapplication because the respondent had never been dismissed within the meaning of that rule. It was further held that the plaintiff was entitled to maintain the suit for arrears of pay in view of the decision of the Federal Court in Tara Chand Pandits case

facts.text: Reinstatement not by appellate or revising authority but by defendant after realizing untenability.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the reinstatement of the plaintiff the telegram of the 30th December, 1943, was number made at the instance of any of the authorities mentioned in the rule in exercise of their jurisdiction, appellate, or revisional, but was made at the instance of the defendant in the suit who had realised that it was number possible to defend the order of dismissal.

The respondent here was dismissed by the Deputy Inspector-General of Police, though he was appointed by the Inspector-General of Police. This was clearly contrary to the  1  1947 F.C.R. 89.  2  75 I.A. 225.  3  75 I.A. 343. provisions of section 240  3  of the Government of India Act, 1935, which provides that no person shall be dismissed from the service of His Majesty by an authority subordinate to that by which he was appointed.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 95 of the Bihar and Orissa Service Code provides Rule 95 When the suspension of a Government servant as a penalty for misconduct is, upon reconsideration or appeal, held to have been unjustifiable or not wholly justifiable or when a Government servant who has been dismissed or removed, or suspended pending enquiry into alleged misconduct is reinstated the revising or appellate authority may grant to him for the period of his absence from duty  a  if he is honourably acquitted, the full pay to which he would have been entitled if he had not been dismissed, removed or suspended

concepts.interpretation: Inapplicable where reinstatement is not by revising or appellate authority but by government after suit, recognizing invalidity of dismissal.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that rule 95 of the Bihar and Orissa Service Code had no application to the facts and circumstances of this case and that the enabling provisions of this rule did not operate as a bar to the plaintiff's action.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we are of the opinion that the High Court was right in holding that rule 95 had no application to the facts and circumstances of this case and that the enabling provisions of this rule did not operate as a bar to the plaintiffs action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 95 applies only to reinstatement by revising or appellate authority; here dismissal invalid under s240(3) and reinstatement by government post-suit recognizing nullity.

holdings.text: The dismissal of the respondent by the Deputy Inspector-General of Police was contrary to section 240(3) of the Government of India Act, 1935, as he was appointed by the Inspector-General of Police.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent here was dismissed by the Deputy Inspector-General of Police, though he was appointed by the Inspector-General of Police. holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of statutory prohibition on dismissal by subordinate authority.

holdings.text: A suit by a public servant against the State for recovery of arrears of salary is competent and maintainable in a civil court.

anchor.surface_text: we think that the rule of English law that a civil servant cannot maintain a suit against the State or against the Crown for the recovery of arrears of salary does not prevail in this country and that it has been negatived by the provisions of the statute law in India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Federal Court in Tara Chand correct; English prerogative not applicable; CPC s60 allows attachment of salary implying direct suit; pleasure doctrine limited to tenure.

holdings.text: The rule of English law that a civil servant cannot sue the Crown for arrears of salary does not prevail in India due to provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: CPC s60 permits creditors to attach salary; inconsistent to deny servant direct suit; historical continuity under GIA s292; no petition of right in India.

holdings.text: The expression 'holds office during His Majesty's pleasure' concerns tenure of office and does not imply salary is a bounty or bar suit for arrears on quantum meruit.

anchor.surface_text: The expression concerns itself with the tenure of office of the civil servant and it is not implicit in it that a civil servant serves the Crown ex gratia or that his salary is in the nature of a bounty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual/purposive interpretation; pleasure rule from common law/statute limits termination, not earned salary rights enforceable under CPC.
